segmentation: OK, so my name is Sabrina Crown and I'm here to talk about our very special project.
So special stands for Scalable Policy Aware Link data architecture for privacy, transparency and compliance.
But we just like to call it special.

So essentially the project is looking to support the general data protection Regulation, so the GPR will come into effect in May next year and essentially companies will have to provide much more control to their customers with respect to their personal data.
And there are also going to have to provide transparency on all of the processing.
All of the sharing even if they gather data about you from public sources.
So essentially our project is looking to support three different stakeholders.
We're looking to support the companies because these companies want to adhere to the GDP or.
We're looking to support the data subjects because we want to help them to digest the information that they're getting from the companies.
But also we want to support the regulators because how are they actually going to enforce this?
And this is a big question and it's very, very topical at the moment because we have only one more year before it comes into force.
So essentially what we're looking at is data and data driven services.
It's a big data project, so therefore we have a number of technology providers and scientific researchers.
The project, the coordination is actually split on the project, so are some W 3C.
Do the administrative coordination and vu do the scientific technical coordination?
So we also have a data protection Officer because it's really important that we have somebody looking after the data subjects interest.
And in terms of our industry partners, essentially we needed big data.
So we went out and we found big data.

So we have two telecom operators, so one is Deutsche Telecom and particularly we're working with T labs there and the other is proximous which is essentially the technical arm of Belgium and the other is Thomson Reuters and essentially their business will be severely impacted by the GDP are because they depends on personal data.
So when it comes to the project, what they would like to do is they.
I'd like to essentially.

Define policy's in a machine readable fashion and the reason why they wanted to find the policies in a machine readable fashion is they want to be able to give different levels of granularity to the customer.
So some people are very lazy and they don't want to actually drill down too much and set specific settings.
So we want to abstract that and make it easier for them.
But some people want a lot of control, so therefore we also want to support them.
So essentially it's going to be all about users control informed consent.
How do I get the consent for the processing?
Then they need to provide all of the information about all of the processing, all of the sharing to the data subject.
Or their customer.

Essentially it's the same person, so this is very very difficult, because if you think of your utility providers and all the data that they capture about you, would you be able to actually digest that data easily?
And what about the sharing of data?
And what if you decide that you want more control?
Well then you got different versions.
You've got different policy's over different years, so you have to manage all of those things.
And we need to do it in a scalable fashion.
So essentially we're talking about a full link data architecture, which can scale.
Is elastic an also is robust in terms of performance and security.
So this is our architecture, so we only started in January, but we are not starting from scratch so we're building on two other projects.
One is big data Europe and the other one is primelife.
So Big data Europe essentially will provide us with the infrastructure that we need for the big data aspects.
And the prime life gives us input on what has worked well in terms of informed consent in the past.
And what are the challenges that are there.
But essentially I'll just take you through a very quickly.
So the first thing is on the left hand side here.
We don't expect that our clients that Thomson Reuters, Belgium, COM and Deutsche Telecom will actually have their data as linked data.
So the first thing we need to do is we need to cement ifai that data.
Maybe we take all the data into a particular infrastructure.

Maybe not, maybe we just actually have a connection, and because the reason why we need to have this connection is we need to be able to associate a policy with the data and the policy will be using semantic technology.
So once we've managed to associate policy with the with the data, the next thing we need to do is we need to.
Compress that data, encrypt that data because we're talking about personal data and personal data, is sensitive and we're talking about personal data in a big data environment.
So therefore we need to both compress it an encrypt it at the same time.
Then what if we actually share the data?
So company a?
Since the data company be when we need to be able to attach the original policy and send the policy with the data and this is called the sticky policy.

But we also need to do this in a way that we have full trace ability and This is why we're using the link data architecture because if we use link data means that as a data subject I can take all of my utility providers and I can put all of that together and I can see the data being transferred and I can see the policy that I placed on the data originally.
And I can see the policy when it's gone to the second company, the recipient.
We also need to query this.
But if it's compressed, and if it's encrypted, we're actually talking about querying compressed encrypted data, taking into account the policies.
And as I said earlier, The thing is we also need to have a user interface which can support the customers in understanding what's happening where.
There's a lot of data there.
So essentially we offer these things.
We offer their transparency framework, the policy language, the encryption and compression combined, and what we're interested in is gathering requirements.
We're interested in existing tools and techniques for querying and reasoning over policies in particular, and we're also interested in visualizing the RDF data.
OK.
